I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  At the request of the Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) during the 
PRC country programming mission in December 2010, technical assistance (TA) for Strategies 
for Green Jobs Creation and Promotion1 was included in the 2011 nonlending program of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB).  ADB  undertook  a  TA  fact-finding  mission  in  June  2011. 
Agreement was reached with the government, including the Ministry of Finance and the Ministry 
of Human Resources and Social Security (MOHRSS), on the TA’s impact, outcome, outputs, 
costs and financing, implementation arrangements, and outline terms of reference for consulting 
services. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  As a rapidly developing country with a large population and a fragile eco-environment, 
the PRC is vulnerable to the adverse effects of climate change. In just three decades from 1978, 
the PRC has become the world’s second-largest economy, and such growth and expansion 
have  had  a  significant  impact  on  the  country’s  eco-environment.  The  government  has 
emphasized  the  need to  build  an  environmentally  sustainable  and  energy-efficient  society, 
transitioning to a low-carbon economy and promoting green jobs2 under its Twelfth Five-Year 
Plan  (2011–2015).  The  government  has  taken  significant  steps  in  this  direction.  The 
government’s spending on  research  and  development  has  increased from  1.25%  of gross 
domestic product in 2004 to 1.5% of a bigger gross domestic product in 2008.3 The solar 
industry  in  the  PRC  is  gaining  importance  in  the  “clean-tech”  global  marketplace,  with  its 
investment across the clean technology sector reaching $13.5 billion in the third quarter of 
2010.4 The PRC is engaged in carbon trading through the Clean Development Mechanism, a 
carbon emission credit system under the Kyoto Protocol. Local initiatives, from green growth 
incubators to eco-villages and to development of green cities are gaining traction in the PRC. 
The central government has emphasized the importance of promoting green jobs, including 
introducing the concept and raising awareness of green jobs among the government and the 
public  through  advocacy  initiatives;  conducting  strategic  research  on  green  jobs  to  inform 
policies and strategies, including issues of unemployment and redeployment; strengthening 
skills training for green jobs; and encouraging innovation in green and clean sectors to spur 
green employment.5 The government targets to create 2.2 million green jobs by 2020. 
 
3.  The recent global recession has emphasized the need for policy interventions aimed at 
encouraging recovery and renewed growth on more environmentally and socially sustainable 
grounds.  There  is  a  growing  need  to  promote  job  creation  in  new  sectors  and  increase 
productivity levels across all sectors, which will be the key driver of growth. This requires greater 
cohesion between the industrial, environmental protection, and employment promotion policies. 
There is a need for a broad, integrated mix of policies in order to achieve strong green growth

and promote a green economy, including a focus on market-based approaches and regulations, 
encouraging investment in green technologies, fostering innovation, and investment in research 
and  development.  Achieving  greener growth  and  a greener  economy  will  involve  not  only 
seizing  opportunities  to  develop  new  green  industries,  jobs,  and  technologies,  but  also 
managing  the  transition  for  greening  the  more  traditional  sectors  with  the  associated 
employment and distributional effects. While there is a prospect of additional green jobs,6 the 
long-term impact on employment is uncertain across most green growth scenarios. The costs 
associated  with  green  growth  may  include  job  displacement  or  job  destruction  in  some 
traditional industries. Some jobs will be substituted or redefined. Therefore, one of the main 
challenges will be to facilitate reallocation of capital and labor across sectors while minimizing 
the resulting adjustment costs. Adjustment risks entailed in the PRC’s transition to a low carbon 
economy,  particularly  on  job  losses  and  re-employment  due  to  market  failures  and  skill 
mismatches, will need to be analyzed. 
 
4.  Inclusive  green  growth  and  green  pathways  out  of  poverty.  In  light  of  the 
government’s goal of building a harmonious society and given the nexus between climate 
change, environmental factors, and poverty, it is important to assess how green jobs can serve 
as “green pathways out of poverty.” This involves seeing green growth within the national 
poverty reduction policy framework, assessing positive and negative impacts of green growth 
scenarios on poverty reduction, and stimulating participation of poor and vulnerable populations 
in the green economy. Anticipating and adapting to the social and economic effects of climate 
change can involve widening employment opportunities, including for the poor, on a sustainable 
basis.7 For instance, migrant workers in the PRC are among the most vulnerable to economic 
changes and their job opportunities were affected by the global recession in 2009.8 Green jobs 
could provide new opportunities for migrants. A pro-poor green jobs strategy needs to address 
the issue of decent work (good jobs which offer adequate wages, safe working conditions, job 
security, reasonable career prospects, social security benefits, and promotion of workers’ rights) 
and the sustainability of job creation for lower-income groups and the poor, as well as its 
systemic impact on the labor market. Furthermore, climate change has gender dimensions in 
both urban and rural areas. Women, while accounting for less than 50% of all migrant workers 
nationwide, tend to concentrate in a narrow range of jobs and industries. For example, young 
women workers from other provinces dominate large manufacturing and processing plants in 
coastal urban areas. Issues specific to women migrant workers must be systematically reviewed, 
and  green  jobs  strategies  must  be  tailored  to  their  special  needs.  Further,  monitoring  of 
employment data by gender needs to be strengthened. 
 
5.  Training for green skills. There is a growing recognition that almost all jobs will require 
green  skills  to  some  degree  and  that  these  may  be  developed  incrementally.  While  the 
development  of  green  technologies  will  require  scientific  technological  engineering  and 
mathematic skills, many of the changes within jobs will require not novel or special skills but 
better generic competencies, such as environmental awareness; entrepreneurship; adaptability; 
and strategic, innovation, and marketing skills. This requires the strengthening of training and

skills development at both the industry and public sector levels. Greater policy coherence will 
ensure  that  both  economic  and  environmental  policy  objectives  are  supported  by  skills 
development.  The  skills  development  strategy  should  also  look  at  the  low-skilled  workers’ 
inclusion in the changing labor market, mainly migrant workers who represent a large part of the 
labor force. Some emphasis should also be placed on retraining versus new training needs and 
on a tailored approach to retraining various target groups (e.g., by gender, age), given that local 
governments are attempting to shift their local economies and regular technical and vocational 
education and training approaches often do not adequately address the emerging needs. The 
TA will assist the central government in the following specific areas: (i) analyzing the potential 
for green jobs creation in the context of green growth; (ii) assessing linkages between green 
growth and poverty reduction by analyzing the potential for decent green jobs as “pathways out 
of poverty” for low-income and vulnerable groups, including migrant workers, women, and youth; 
(iii) assessing the gender dimensions of green jobs potential; (iv) fostering consultations among 
stakeholders to promote green jobs, including for the lower-income population and vulnerable 
groups; (v) assessing training and retraining needs, including for vulnerable groups; and (vi) 
making policy recommendations for the creation and promotion of green employment under the 
Twelfth Five-Year Plan, to help the PRC accelerate its transition to a low carbon economy. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The impact of the TA is strengthened capacity of the government and other stakeholders 
for promoting and creating green jobs in the PRC. The outcome will be a comprehensive 
analysis and development of a preliminary national framework for promoting green jobs. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  The TA outputs will be (i) policy recommendations for promoting and creating green jobs 
at the national level, (ii) policy recommendations for promoting and creating pro-poor green jobs 
at  the  national  level,  and  (iii)  widely  disseminated  publications  on  key  TA  findings  and 
recommendations. Creation of a national framework for green jobs requires that policies be 
explored, developed, and promoted at the provincial level. Therefore, two provinces from the 
PRC’s central and coastal regions (to be determined during TA implementation) will be selected 
as case studies to pilot assessment and development of green jobs policies. The TA activities 
include a desk study, interviews with government officials, surveys, field trips to the two pilot 
provinces, seminars and workshops in Beijing, an overseas study tour, and a wrap-up green 
jobs forum in Beijing. The desk study will review national and international experiences in green 
jobs creation. Field work in pilot provinces will include visits to and surveys of key enterprises in 
selected  industries  and  organizations  and  interviews  with  officials  in  relevant  government 
agencies (e.g.,  Provincial  Development  and  Reform  Commission,  Environmental  Protection 
Bureau, Finance Bureau, Energy Office, Human Resources and Social Security Department, 
and Poverty Alleviation Department). Participants in an overseas study tour, who will include 
officials from the central government who make and implement policies relating to green jobs 
and selected TA consultants, will be able to (i) observe good practices in a country with rich 
experience in green jobs creation, and (ii) exchange experiences and lessons learned with 
officials from other countries. The TA will facilitate consultations at the national and provincial 
level to support policy formulation on green jobs. Detailed consultations will be carried out with 
the concerned stakeholders, including the private sector, employers’ associations, trade unions, 
worker associations and representative groups, civil society, government agencies, research 
institutes, and international organizations. Workshops and a green jobs forum will serve as a

4   
platform for (i) sharing TA findings at various stages, (ii) getting feedback for improving TA work 
and findings, and (iii) building consensus among TA stakeholders on key recommendations for 
government and private sector action. The TA will also establish a green jobs knowledge hub9 
intended to facilitate information and experience exchange in green job strategies that can be 
applied within the PRC and elsewhere in the Asia and Pacific region. The TA outputs will 
include one main report and three subreports. 
 
8.  Main technical assistance report on green jobs creation and promotion. The main 
report will include (i) an analysis of the PRC’s current policies and regulations intended to 
achieve  green  growth  and  a  transition  to  a  low-carbon  economy,  including  market-based 
approaches  and  regulations;  encouraging  investment  in  green  technologies;  and  fostering 
innovation, investment in research and development, and skills development polices; (ii) a 
working definition of green jobs, green growth, and green economy based on stakeholder 
consultations during the TA workshops and seminars; (iii) an analysis of the long-term impact of 
green  growth  policies  on  employment,  including  job  displacement  and  job  destruction  in 
traditional industries; (iv) an analysis of current and future employment patterns and skills 
profiles in selected green industries and the restructuring of brown industries in the PRC; (v) an 
analysis of potential job creation in selected industries and subsectors, such as modern service 
industries; advanced manufacturing industries; strategic, high-tech, and emerging industries; 
traditional industries; and agriculture in pilot provinces; (vi) a discussion of the policy conditions 
that are needed for the development of green employment, including for the poor population; 
and  (vii)  recommendations  for  ways  to  achieve  greater  cohesion  between  the  industrial, 
environmental protection, and employment promotion policies. The main report should also 
provide recommendations for policy, legal, regulatory, and administrative reforms. The main 
report will review international experiences in green jobs creation and promotion. The three 
subreports will be on: (i) Pro-poor green jobs policies. Topics will include (a) an analysis of 
green  jobs  creation  as  “pathways  out  of  poverty”  for  migrant  workers,  poor  women, 
underemployed  youth, and  low-skilled  workers’  inclusion  in the  changing  labor market,  (b) 
identifying priority sectors where green jobs for the poor populations can be created,  (c) 
recommendations for policies supportive of pro-poor green jobs. The subreport will also include 
a gender analysis of job opportunities and training needs in the green economy, focusing on 
women migrant workers. (ii) Skills  training  and  capacity  building. Topics will include an 
assessment of implications for skills training and retraining and capacity building, including 
identifying the required level of “skills upgrade” or “skills shift”; and identifying the training needs 
of  disadvantaged  groups,  including  low-income  migrant  labor.  Recommendations  for  skills 
development policies and management of training providers should be included. (iii) Green jobs 
creation in the two pilot provinces. This subreport will be based on case studies of green jobs 
creation in pilot areas (one in central and one in coastal PRC). Case studies will include visits to 
and surveys of key enterprises in selected industries and organizations and interviews with 
officials in relevant government agencies in the pilot provinces. The subreport will provide labor 
market projections of green jobs in selected industries, using relevant methodologies. The 
consultants will submit (a) the main TA report, (b) three subreports, (c) a policy note for decision 
makers, (d) a summary report on the green jobs forum, and (e) an executive summary of the 
main TA report. The policy note for decision makers, which presents key findings and major 
                                                
9  The aim of the green jobs knowledge hub is to create knowledge and capacity to promote green jobs and to 
facilitate knowledge sharing and awareness raising on green jobs in the PRC and in the Asia and Pacific region. 
The green jobs knowledge hub will focus on peer group information exchange to develop good practice case 
studies that can be applied to different contexts and can be disseminated to wider audiences. The TA will identify a 
suitable institution to host the green jobs knowledge hub in its initial phase. As the green jobs knowledge hub 
develops, further approaches to knowledge exchange will be used and wider partnerships developed.

policy recommendations of the TA, will be shared with decision makers at the national and local 
levels. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
9.  The government has requested ADB to finance $400,000 equivalent. The TA will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). 
The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office space, 
domestic transportation, provision of communications facilities for consultants, and other in-kind 
contributions. (See Appendix 2 for details of the cost estimates and financing plan.) 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
10.  MOHRSS  will  be  the  executing  and  implementing  agency  for  the  TA.  An 
interdepartmental working group will be set up within the ministry, comprising the International 
Cooperation Department, Employment Promotion Department, Skills Development Department, 
and Policy and Legal Department. The working group will review inception, interim, and final 
reports prepared by the consultants. The TA consultants will incorporate the suggestions of the 
working group into the final reports. Other relevant ministries and agencies will be regularly 
consulted during project implementation. MOHRSS will provide the necessary office space, 
counterpart staff, transportation, and other services to the consultants; and will arrange meeting 
appointments for the consultants with relevant agencies and organizations. A total of 31.5 
person-months of consulting services (one international consultant for 4 person-months and six 
national  consultants  for  27.5  person-months)  will  be  required.  The  TA  consultants  will  be 
engaged on an individual basis in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). Recruitment of individual consultants is considered 
appropriate because (i) green jobs is an emerging area in the PRC and the available pool of 
green jobs experts is limited; and (ii) the TA will likely have a strong impact on the development 
of future green jobs policies in the PRC and, therefore, requires high-quality technical inputs. 
Consultants will have expertise in (i) green jobs policies and implementation; (ii) employment 
policies and a transition to a low-carbon economy; (iii) skills development and training; and (iv) 
social, poverty impact, and gender analysis. The national consultant and expert on green jobs 
strategies will be the team leader. The consultants will be responsible for producing the TA’s 
outputs and deliverables effectively and on time; and for organizing and carrying out all TA 
activities including surveys, field visits, an overseas study tour, training, and workshops. The 
terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix  3. An advance payment facility will be 
established under the TA. All reports will be prepared in English and translated into Chinese. 
Translation costs for project reports will be budgeted and allocated to the consultants. Major 
project activities will be regularly monitored and reported to MOHRSS and ADB administrative 
missions. The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in line with ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA will be implemented 
over a 12-month period. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
11.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Strategies for Green Jobs Creation and 
Promotion, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require the services of seven consultants for a total of 
31.5 person-months, consisting of one international consultant for 4 person-months and six 
national  consultants  for  27.5  person-months,  over  a  period  of  12  months  during  TA 
implementation. The consultants will perform their tasks in close consultation with the executing 
and implementing agency, the Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security (MOHRSS), 
and other responsible provincial and local government departments and agencies to ensure full 
acceptance of the outcome of the TA. The consultants shall produce the following in both 
English and Chinese: (i) the main TA report, (ii) three subreports, (iii) a policy note for decision 
makers, (iv) a summary report on the green jobs forum, and (v) an executive summary of the 
main TA report. The consultants will be responsible for organizing consultative workshops, 
seminars, training, an overseas study tour, and the green jobs forum to present key TA findings. 
All  consultants  shall  be  familiar  with  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC),  including  its 
socioeconomic context. The consultant team will arrange all the necessary translations needed 
for  the  TA  activities.  Consultants  will  have  expertise  in  (i)  green  jobs  policies  and 
implementation, (ii) employment policies and a transition to a low-carbon economy, (iii) skills 
development and training, (iv) social and poverty impact and gender analysis, and (v) labor 
market analysis. The national consultant and expert on green jobs strategies will be the team 
leader. The consultants will deliver the TA’s outputs and deliverables effectively and on time, 
and will organize and carry out all TA activities. National consultants should have the relevant 
educational background, preferably a graduate degree, and at least 5 years of work experience 
in  their  field.  The  international  consultant  should  have  relevant  educational  qualifications, 
preferably a graduate degree, and at least 10 years of work experience in his/her field. 
 
2.  Team leader and expert on green jobs strategies (national, 6.5 person-months). The 
team leader will (i) submit to MOHRSS and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) an inception 
report, as detailed above, which will contain (a) a work plan detailing each team member’s 
inputs (to be updated periodically, as needed), (b) an outline of the main TA report and schedule, 
and  (c)  the  design  and  plans for  conducting surveys  in  pilot  provinces;  (ii)  work  with  the 
international consultant to ensure a clear delineation of responsibilities among team members, 
and with national and local government counterparts in the preparation, implementation, and 
follow-up of the TA survey, reports, workshops, seminars, and other TA activities, including the 
study tour; (iii) work with the international consultant to ensure (a) the implementation of the TA 
according to the terms of reference and any subsequent instructions or guidance that may be 
provided by MOHRSS or ADB, and (b) the timeliness and quality of the consulting team’s 
outputs and deliverables; and will be responsible for (iv) discussing with MOHRSS a selection of 
the two pilot provinces and ensuring MOHRSS selects the two pilot provinces within month 1 of 
TA implementation; (v) a comprehensive review of the central government’s existing policies 
and practices on green jobs, as well as the needs and potential for green jobs in the context of 
the  Twelfth  Five-Year  Plan  and  the  PRC’s  industrial,  environmental,  and  urban  and  rural 
development planning up to 2020. The team leader will first produce a review of the existing 
government  policies  on  green  jobs  and  of  existing  reports  developed  by  the  government, 
associated agencies, and international organizations to map out the current status of green jobs 
promotion. The analysis will also focus on the provision of skills training for green jobs and 
should consider implications of the PRC’s shift to consumption-based economic growth and 
regional rebalancing, as well as current challenges with labor shortages; (vi) a comprehensive 
analysis of green jobs strategies in pilot provinces in selected industries and subsectors, such 
as  modern  service  industries;  advanced  manufacturing  industries;  strategic,  high-tech,  and 
emerging industries; traditional industries; and agriculture. This analysis will be carried out 
through  (a)  a  desk  review  of  existing  data  and  documents;  (b)  field  trips  and  surveys  of

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
enterprises; and (c) in-depth interviews with relevant government officials from government 
agencies in pilot provinces. The team leader will develop draft survey instruments and detailed 
interview  guides,  and  will  be  responsible  for  data  analysis  and  interpretation,  in  close 
consultation with the international specialist on green growth strategies; (vii) ensuring that the 
TA’s analytical approach takes into account and builds on the analytical and technical work on 
green  jobs  in  the  PRC  by  international  organizations,  such  as  the  International  Labour 
Organization (ILO) and Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) to 
avoid  duplication  of  efforts  and  to  ensure  cross-agency  coordination  and  coherence  of 
assessment and analytical tools; (viii) preparing the main report to include (a) an analysis of the 
PRC’s current policies and regulations intended to achieve green growth and a transition to a 
low-carbon economy, including market-based approaches, encouraging investment in green 
technologies,  fostering  innovation,  investment  in  research  and  development,  and  skills 
development; (b) a working definition of green jobs, green growth and green economy based on 
stakeholder consultations during the TA workshops and seminars; (c) the long-term impact of 
green growth policies on employment, including job displacement and job destruction during the 
PRC’s transition to a low-carbon economy; (d) an analysis of current and future employment 
patterns and skills profiles in green industries, and the restructuring of brown industries in the 
PRC; (e) an analysis of potential job creation in selected industries and subsectors, such as 
modern  service  industries;  advanced  manufacturing  industries;  strategic,  high-tech,  and 
emerging industries; traditional industries; and agriculture; and (f) a discussion of the policy 
conditions that are needed for the development of pro-poor green employment. The main report 
will  also  need  to  provide  recommendations  for  policy,  legal, regulatory,  and  administrative 
reforms. Recommendations for awareness raising on green jobs and skills development among 
the general public and domestic private companies should also be considered; (ix) producing 
the three subreports on (a) pro-poor green jobs policies; (b) skills training and capacity building; 
and (c) green jobs creation in the two pilot provinces, as indicated in the TA report; (x) a 
comprehensive analysis of the potential for green jobs in selected industries using relevant 
methodologies; and (xi) will ensure that gender and social analysis is conducted, focusing on 
migrant women and vulnerable groups, and that the analysis is included in all reports. Green 
jobs as “pathways out of poverty” should receive specific attention in the analysis, focusing on 
decent work for the most vulnerable: migrants, women, and youth; such an analysis should 
identify linkages between green growth and poverty reduction policies, identify priority sectors 
where green jobs for the poor populations can be created, and recommend policies supportive 
of pro-poor green jobs. The subreport will also include a gender analysis of job opportunities 
and training needs in the green economy, focusing on women migrant workers; (xii) on the basis 
of the above, be responsible for identifying green jobs strategies and pro-poor green jobs at the 
national  level,  and  for  recommending  effective  mechanisms  and  measures  to  foster  and 
promote green jobs, including for the poor population. The recommendations made should be 
clear and specific, should be costed, and should have a prioritized implementation schedule; 
(xiii) together with the team members, identify, through a sample survey, knowledge, attitudes, 
and strategies for green jobs among selected enterprises, and how they can contribute to 
fostering green jobs; (xiv) be responsible for ensuring the quality of the surveys and interviews 
with government departments on green jobs to be conducted in pilot provinces, especially with 
regard to the methodology used in survey design and implementation, and the systematic 
review  and  analysis  of  the  survey  results;  (xv)  be  responsible  for  conducting  detailed 
consultations with concerned stakeholders, including employers’ associations, trade unions, 
worker associations and representative groups, civil society, government agencies, research 
institutes, and international organizations through workshops and the green jobs forum; (xvi) be 
responsible for setting up a green jobs knowledge hub for the duration of the TA and actively 
spearhead efforts to engage with the government, the private sector, international organizations, 
and other stakeholders to garner support for the sustained operation of the hub; (xvii) help

Appendix 3  11 
MOHRSS organize the overseas study tour and lead the MOHRSS team on the study tour; (xviii) 
be responsible for ensuring the quality of the TA’s final main report and subreports; (xix) be 
responsible for preparing, on the basis of the main TA report and technical reports, (a) a concise 
executive summary focusing on key findings and policy recommendations, (b) a policy note for 
decision makers, and (c) a report on the green jobs forum; and (xx) be responsible for preparing 
and finalizing publications based on the TA outputs and reports, and perform other tasks as 
reasonably assigned by MOHRSS and ADB. 
 
3.  Specialist on green jobs strategies (international, 4 person-months). The specialist 
will (i) review the outline terms of reference for consultants and provide suggestions for fine-
tuning them at the beginning of the TA, in consultation with ADB, MOHRSS, and the team 
leader; (ii) provide support to the team leader and national consultants on all aspects of TA 
implementation, including support, as required, on TA surveys, reports, workshops, seminars, 
and other TA activities; (iii) be responsible for systematically introducing advanced international 
experience  on  green  jobs  strategies  from  countries  with  such  experience,  as  well  as 
international  organizations  with  expertise  in  this  area.  Materials  thus  collected  should  be 
compiled as a chapter for the main report. The chapter outline should be provided at TA 
inception;  (iv)  based  on  international  good  practices,  prepare  research  inputs  on  various 
aspects of green job creation and promotion, as requested by the team leader and national 
consultants; (v) work with the team leader to prepare a comprehensive review of existing 
policies and practices on green jobs, as well as the potential for green jobs in the context of the 
Twelfth Five-Year Plan and industrial, environmental, and urban and rural development planning 
up to 2020; (vi) work with the national skills development and training specialist to analyze the 
implications for skills training for green jobs, considering the PRC’s shift to a consumption-
based economic growth and regional rebalancing, as well as current challenges with labor 
shortages; (vii) work with the team leader to prepare the main report to include (a) an analysis of 
the PRC’s current policies and regulations intended to achieve green growth and a transition to 
a low-carbon economy, including market-based approaches, encouraging investment in green 
technologies,  fostering  innovation,  investment  in  research  and  development,  and  skills 
development; (b) a working definition of green jobs, green economy and green growth based on 
stakeholder consultations during the TA workshops and seminars; (c) the long-term impact of 
green growth policies on employment, including job displacement and job destruction during the 
PRC’s transition to a low-carbon economy; (d) an analysis of current and future employment 
patterns and skills profiles in green industries, and the restructuring of brown industries in the 
PRC; (e) an analysis of potential job creation in selected industries and subsectors, such as 
modern  service  industries;  advanced  manufacturing  industries;  strategic,  high-tech,  and 
emerging industries; traditional industries; and agriculture; and (f) a discussion of the policy 
conditions that are needed for the development of pro-poor green employment. The expert will 
be responsible for the subreport on pro-poor green jobs, focusing on decent work for the most 
vulnerable: migrants, women, and youth; such an analysis should identify linkages between 
green growth and poverty reduction policies, identify priority sectors where green jobs for the 
poor populations can be created, and recommend policies supportive of pro-poor green jobs. 
The subreport will also include a gender analysis of job opportunities and training needs in the 
green  economy,  focusing  on  women  migrant  workers;  (viii)  with  the  team  leader,  provide 
comments on the following subreports: skills training and capacity building and green jobs 
creation in the two pilot provinces; (ix) engage with regional and international organizations to 
ensure learning from good practices, to avoid duplication of effort, and to identify levels at which 
cooperation would be most effective; (x) provide guidance to the national consultants on social, 
poverty, and gender analyses; (xi) assist the team leader with appropriate methodologies for a 
survey design, sampling, and analysis, as well as methodologies for interviews and stakeholder 
consultations; (xii) work with the team leader to set up a green jobs knowledge hub; prepare a

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
draft  charter,  institutional  framework,  and  operational  plan  for  the  knowledge  hub;  identify 
stakeholders and initial partners; assist in identifying a host institution; and assist in preparing 
the first three case studies on green jobs for dissemination in the PRC and other developing 
countries; (xiii) assist MOHRSS in selecting am appropriate country with rich experience in 
green jobs creation for an overseas study tour; (xiv) assist the team leader in preparing and 
finalizing the executive summary, main report and subreports, and knowledge products; (xv) 
assist the team leader in preparing and organizing workshops, seminars, and the green jobs 
forum; and (xvi) perform other tasks as reasonably assigned by the team leader and ADB.  
 
4.  Expert on labor market analysis (national, 2 person-months). The consultant will (i) 
review the overall provincial economic development plans, including the provincial government’s 
planned investments, as well as green jobs policies and planning in the two pilot provinces; (ii) 
analyze labor market information in the pilot provinces to determine skills gaps and emerging 
labor requirements; (iii) assess the future demand for green jobs in selected industries in pilot 
provinces  and  at the  national  level,  together with the  team  leader; (iv)  be responsible for 
conducting  a  comprehensive  analysis  of  green  jobs  strategies  in  selected  industries  and 
subsectors, such as modern service industries; advanced manufacturing industries; strategic, 
high-tech, and emerging industries; and traditional industries, focusing on projections of green 
jobs in selected industries, using a value chain assessment or other relevant methodologies; (v) 
prepare a chapter for the main report on the potential of green jobs strategies in selected 
industries and subsectors; (vi) work with national specialists on green employment policies on 
looking at the gender and social dimensions of green jobs. Green jobs as “pathways out of 
poverty” should receive specific attention in the analysis, with an emphasis on decent work for 
the  most  vulnerable:  migrants,  women,  and  youth;  (vii)  provide  labor  market  projections, 
analysis,  and  other  inputs to  the  team  leader for  developing  TA reports. Work  with  other 
consultants, and in close consultation with MOHRSS to develop recommendations for green 
jobs strategies; and (viii) assist the team leader in preparing the main report and other reports, 
in preparing and participating in workshops and the conference, and in fulfilling other relevant 
responsibilities assigned by the team leader; and fulfill other tasks as reasonably assigned by 
the team leader and ADB. 
 
5.  Specialists on green employment policies (2 national, 6 person-months each). The 
specialists will (i) prepare a comprehensive assessment of existing policies and practices on 
green jobs at the national level and the two pilot provinces, as background input to the main 
report. The report should also provide systematic information about the PRC’s transition to a 
low-carbon economy to set the context for its focus on green jobs; (ii) in consultation with 
MOHRSS and the stakeholders, establish working definitions of green jobs, green economy, 
and green growth early in the TA implementation; (iii) work with the team leader and the 
international  consultant  to  design  and  conduct  surveys  of  green  jobs  in  pilot  provinces  in 
selected industries and subsectors, such as modern service industries; advanced manufacturing 
industries;  strategic,  high-tech,  and  emerging  industries;  and traditional  industries;  and the 
subsequent systematic analysis of survey results. The survey and field visits should identify and 
assess the potential for green jobs in the context of industrial, environmental, and urban and 
rural development planning in the pilot provinces. Given the limited scope of the TA, such an 
analysis will focus on a sample of enterprises in selected industries. Field work will include visits 
to and surveys of key enterprises and organizations and interviews with officials in relevant 
government agencies in the pilot provinces regarding the impact of economic restructuring on 
green  jobs,  attitudes  toward  green  jobs,  planning  for  green  jobs,  and  the  existing  policy 
framework. The analysis should also assess whether green job opportunities can create “green 
pathways out of poverty” by creating green jobs for the most vulnerable: migrants, women, and 
youth; (iv) provide an assessment on the appropriateness and suitability of all analyses and

Appendix 3  13 
recommendations on measures and mechanisms for creating and promoting green jobs; (v) 
provide a social and gender analysis in all the tasks above, and incorporate the analysis and 
recommendations in all reports and in the surveys; (vi) provide gender analysis on green job 
opportunities and incorporate the analysis and recommendations in all reports and in the survey. 
The survey of enterprises will be designed and conducted to collect sex-disaggregated and 
gender-based data, and the subsequent gender analysis of this data will be incorporated into 
the overall analysis of the survey results; (vii) assist in preparing the green jobs forum and other 
workshops;  (viii)  review  the  overall  provincial  economic  development  plans,  including  the 
provincial government’s planned investments, as well as green jobs policies and planning in the 
pilot provinces; (ix) carry out a social and poverty impact analysis of green job opportunities and 
incorporate the analysis and recommendations into all reports and the survey; (x) based on the 
above  analysis,  identify  training  and  retraining  needs  for  low-income  groups  and  the 
disadvantaged, particularly migrant workers and youth; (xi) analyze how green jobs can be 
linked to poverty reduction and how green jobs can be created for disadvantaged groups and 
incorporate the analysis and recommendations into all reports; (xii) assist the team leader in 
preparing the main report and other reports, and in preparing and participating in the workshops, 
seminars, and other TA activities; and undertake other relevant responsibilities assigned by the 
team  leader;  (xiii)  review  the  overall  provincial  economic  development  plan,  including  the 
provincial government’s planned investments, as well as green jobs policies and planning in the 
pilot provinces; (xiv) help MOHRSS organize an overseas study tour; (xv) based on the above 
analysis,  identify  training  and  retraining  needs  for  green  jobs,  particularly  women  migrant 
workers; and perform other tasks as reasonably assigned by the team leader and ADB. 
 
6.  Skills development and training specialist (national, 3 person-months). This specialist 
will (i) assess the status of vocational education and skills training for green jobs at the national 
level and in the two pilot provinces; identify constraints and opportunities for anticipating and 
mapping  skills  required  for  green  jobs;  and  make  clear  and  specific  recommendations  on 
measures  and  mechanisms  for  improvements,  with  costed  options,  and  a  prioritized 
implementation schedule; (ii) work with other team members to design and conduct surveys of 
green jobs in the pilot provinces. Consider the implications of the PRC’s shift to demand-based 
economic growth, regional rebalancing, and urbanization for green job creation, employment, 
and social safety nets; (iii) assess the training and retraining needs of the most vulnerable, 
migrants, women, and youth, with regard to green job opportunities; (iv) assess the capacity-
building needs of the government agencies (e.g., human resources or the labor department) in 
terms of vocational education and skills training for green jobs, including needs arising from the 
survey results and other TA activities; and propose capacity-building plans to mitigate the 
constraints. The plans should be phased and should explore training-the-trainers and other 
tested capacity-building approaches; and (v) help the team leader prepare and finalize the main 
report and other reports, and prepare and participate in the workshops and conference; and 
undertake other relevant responsibilities assigned by the team leader.  
 
7.  Project coordinator (national, 4 person-months). The project coordinator will help with 
overall TA administration and with coordinating consultants’ work; help organize consultative 
meetings, workshops, and a green jobs forum, including providing logistical support such as 
booking the venue, accommodation, and meals; send invitations, arrange for translation, and 
prepare printing materials; help organize the study tour, training, and field surveys; assist with 
establishing the green jobs knowledge hub; assist with logistical support in report preparation, 
dissemination, and publication of knowledge products; help the TA consultants prepare time 
sheets, invoices, and other relevant documentation and submit them in a timely manner; be 
responsible for administering all costs associated with the study tour and the workshops; assist 
MOHRSS and the consultants with submitting the required documentation for the study tour,

14  Appendix 3 
 
 
workshops,  and  other  related  TA  activities;  participate  in  ADB  missions  as  required,  and 
undertake other relevant responsibilities assigned by ADB.
